Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
The work of tending to the broken, the hurting, the cast aside, that's the path I see myself walking. The Division of Family and Children Services. Places like that. Where the wounds are deep and the shadows long. Where the broken families and the abused children gather. These are the things that call to me.

Service, respect, ethics. These are not just words on a page, they're the stones that build the foundation of a life worth living. They're the light in the darkness. And they're the tools I'll use to mend what's been torn apart.

I've always felt it, this pull towards helping. A need to reach out, to offer a hand to those lost in the wilderness. I saw it in the faces of my classmates, the ones who ran from their own demons, the ones who choked down their pain with substances that offered only a fleeting peace.

A degree in psychology, that was the path I chose. A path that led me to a crossroads. A summer day, a friend's couch, a silhouetted boy, sixteen years old and trembling. He was running from his own hell, from the hands that should have protected him. I saw the fear in his eyes, the desperate plea for help.

I went to his house, to the place where the shadows gathered. I spoke to the police, a voice of reason in the face of indifference. I spoke to the parents, their words a flimsy shield against the truth. They were masters of denial, of twisting reality to fit their own broken narratives.

That day, I knew. I knew that the law couldn't mend the brokenness, couldn't reach the heart of the darkness. Social work, that's where I belonged.  I wanted to be the one to fight for those who couldn't fight for themselves.

And then there's justice. The kind that whispers in the corners of our souls, the kind that demands we stand up and fight for the downtrodden, the forgotten.

We claim to value the individual, yet we strive to make them all the same. A sterile uniformity, a conformity that crushes the spirit. I've never been one to follow the flock. My hair, my clothes, my piercings, they are a testament to my refusal to be a puppet on a string.

I've fought against injustice wherever I've seen it, a solitary voice crying out in the wilderness. Racism, discrimination, I've stood against them all. And I will continue to do so, for the world needs more voices, more hearts that refuse to be silenced.

The paper turns its gaze upon the twin specters of sleeplessness: the Biological and the Sociocultural. The first, a matter of genes and the body's frail machinery, whispers of inherited predispositions and the hardwiring of ailment. The second, a phantom born of circumstance, examines the world's grip on the slumbering mind. It probes the loam of race, ethnicity, and the stony weight of circumstance, seeking the roots of unrest. This review delves into these models, laying bare the research that seeks to illuminate their dark corners. For each study, we'll dissect the findings, weighing their strengths against their frailties, seeking the truth that flickers in the shadows. 

Sleep itself, a fragile thing, can be a prisoner to many masters. It can be a primary affliction, a ghost haunting the mind, or a shadow cast by some deeper malady. The primary sleep disorders, the Dyssomnias, are a bleak procession: Insomnia, where sleep eludes, Hypersomnia, where wakefulness is a burden, Narcolepsy, a cruel parody of rest, Breathing-Related Sleep Disorders, where the breath itself betrays, Circadian Rhythm Sleep Disorder, a life out of sync with the sun, and Dyssomnia Not Otherwise Specified, a category for the nameless terrors. Then there are the Parasomnias, where the body betrays the mind in its dreams, manifesting as Nightmares, Sleep Terrors, and Sleepwalking. And finally, sleep can be a casualty in the wars fought on the battlefields of the mind, a symptom of the deep-seated wounds of Clinical or Personality Disorders.  

This review, however, focuses its light on insomnia, a plague that touches many lives, and the twin models that seek to understand its grip. The Biological model, a cold and clinical lens, zeroes in on the genes, the inherited predispositions, and the physiological mechanisms that govern sleep. It points to the neurons in the hypothalamus, their orexin-filled chambers the gatekeepers of slumber and wakefulness. A study, conducted in the silent world of mice, revealed that these neurons possess GABAB receptors, sensitive to the touch of certain chemicals. When these receptors are activated, sleep descends. But if they are silenced, anxiety melts away, and sleep's embrace becomes more inviting. This study, using the humble mouse as a stand-in for man, suggests that there is a genetic, and perhaps environmental, basis for these receptors. A flaw in their design, a glitch in the system, could leave a person adrift in a sea of sleepless nights, forever yearning for the solace of rest. The Sociocultural model, peering through a different lens, suggests that these inherited vulnerabilities are shaped by the world around us. If a predisposition to sleeplessness is passed down through generations, it could become a chain that binds, a legacy of unrest. This could manifest in the struggles of daily life, in the shadows cast by school, work, and the unending cycle of mundane tasks.

This paper bleeds three wounds open: the nature of the disorder, the hunt for its signs, and the ways a shepherd of young minds might tend a lamb burdened by it.  

Central Auditory Processing Disorder, or CAPD, some call it. Auditory Processing Disorder too. It’s the way the mind, that dark chamber of the skull, makes sense of the sounds that crowd in.  A broken record skipping, failing to spin the music whole. They hear, these children, but the words fall like stones on hard ground, the music a blur. The brain, it misfires,  unable to sift the wheat from the chaff, the signal from the noise.

The whispers started in the mid-century, calling it “auditory imperception.”  Italian hands, Bocca, Calearo, Cassinari, first reached out to measure the silence in these children’s minds. Then Kimura, a ghost in the machine, wove the web of dichotic testing, seeking the phantom thread that bound sound to meaning.

The signs, they wear many faces. A child lost in a roomful of voices, unable to pinpoint the source. Sounds bleed into one another, indistinguishable, like water merging with the sky. Patterns, they elude them, slipping through their grasp like smoke. They hear a word, but its meaning, it hangs in the air, a distant echo.

To diagnose, to pierce the veil, they watch, they listen. Tests, they offer,  a barrage of sounds, a symphony of chaos. A child sifts through the noise, searching for the thread that binds, for the meaning that eludes. But there is no single key, no map to navigate  this labyrinthine mind. And the cause, it remains a shadow, a mystery whispered in the silence.

The play, Twelfth Night, strikes a bleak note on the nature of disguise.  It shows how a mask can be useful in weaving a web of deceit,  how it can shield and protect. But there's a price. To shed the mask, to face the truth, is to risk unraveling oneself. The world beyond the disguise can be unforgiving.  

To reveal the lie is to invite judgment, to cast oneself adrift in a sea of misunderstanding. Some may turn away, their faces etched with scorn. Others may harbor resentment, their words like shards of glass.  It is a choice then, a stark one: the preservation of the self, or the bonds of those around.

The play grapples with this most keenly when the disguise takes on the weight of gender. Why would someone renounce their own identity, assume the mantle of the other? In Viola's case, it is a desperate act of survival. To be a woman in a harsh world is to be vulnerable. She adopts the guise of Cesario, a protector, a shield against the darkness.

Yet, this act of self-preservation creates a gulf between her and the women she once knew. She is cut off from their solace, their shared understanding.  And the deception deepens. Olivia, drawn to the illusion of Cesario, mistakes her for Sebastian, her heart entangled in a web of misdirection.  And Orsino, her affections tangled with the fabricated persona, yearns for a love that cannot be.

Is this a modern lens we see through, or is there something deeper at play? Perhaps the play hints at suppressed desires, emotions lurking beneath the surface, brought to light by the artifice of Viola's disguise.  Does Olivia's attraction to Cesario stem from a deeper truth, a secret longing? Or is it a reflection of the shallowness of the world around her, a world that judges by appearances alone?

When the mask falls, and the truth is revealed, Olivia's affections shift with the ease of a summer breeze, from Cesario to Sebastian.  She embraces Viola as sister, the deception forgiven, the bonds of blood taking precedence.

The German hand, they say, was heavy on the land. Not for nothing did the whisper of genocide hang over the Ovaherero and Nama in South West Africa. But an empire, vast and sprawling, can't be measured by such simple reckonings. The German dominion was a patchwork, its policies and ways as varied as the landscapes it claimed. And so it was with education. Some lands, like East Africa, saw the Kaiser's hand in schools and literacy, a bloom of knowledge under the watchful eye of the state. Others, well, others were left to the tending of missionaries, their faith a meager harvest in the arid plains.

South West Africa was one such land. Not the grand schools of Tanganyika, where the natives were groomed under the watchful gaze of the crown. Here, the task fell to men of God, their offerings sparse, their reach limited. The Kaiser, however, saw to the education of his own, a system of state schools erected, a careful hand guiding the missionaries. The long shadow of this division stretched far into the future, even after the German eagle had flown. While other lands boasted men of letters, South West Africa remained largely untouched, the vast majority unlettered, unschooled, their destinies bound to the unforgiving earth.

This land, this South West Africa, was a study in contrasts. It asks the question: what forces shaped this divergence? What lay in the hearts of those who claimed ownership, those who sought to mold the destinies of others? This paper seeks to explore those answers, to plumb the depths of history and uncover the truths hidden beneath the sands of time.

The tales of German education are many, spun in German tongue and penned by those who lived it. They speak of systems, of structures, of the ways knowledge was dispensed. Later, voices from beyond the German borders echoed these stories, comparing and contrasting, dissecting the tapestry of colonial education.  Among these voices, Cohen's stands out, a beacon in the darkness. He peered into the heart of South West Africa and East Africa, seeking the reasons behind their differing trajectories. The answer, he found, lay in the settlers, their numbers, their desires.

South West Africa, compared to other colonies, held a temperate embrace, though the desert stretched across much of its face. It was a land that drew the European to its shores. By 1913, nearly fifteen thousand whites had found a home there, a far cry from the five thousand in East Africa, the next most populated colony.

The music called Popular, a hundred years spilled across the land,  has come to wear a thousand faces.  Rock and rap, country and jazz, folk and a hundred whispers in between. Each a tangled knot of branches, bearing sub-genres and sub-sub-genres like fruit heavy on the bough. 

Heavy metal, born in the furnace of the last forty years, sings a song of darkness. Its voice, a cacophony of noise and feeling, leans into the shadows. It is a music of excess, a hunger for more, more bass, more volume, more violence, more theatricality.  It erupted from the earth, a fist clenched tight, demanding to be heard. 

Early on, men and women found the metal sound could bend, could be shaped to their will. Each carved a niche, a sub-genre, a voice within the roar. The branches spread, a tangled forest of sound.

Today, the metal movement stands vast and complex.  Its roots lie buried deep, but its branches reach for the sky. To understand the metal of today, one must first know the metal of yesterday, the fire that birthed it.

Metal, in its essence, is a song of darkness. It is a music of the primal, the visceral, the raw. It is a music born of excess, of drugs and despair, of a hunger that cannot be satiated. The psychedelic haze of the seventies stirred the soul, birthing music that was both beautiful and terrifying. 

It is a music that reminds us of the darkness within, the shadows that lurk at the edge of our vision. It is a music that does not shy away from the bleak realities of life, but embraces them, holds them up to the light. 

Lyrics like those from "Helter Skelter" whisper of this darkness. The Beatles, those purveyors of sunshine and love, delved into the abyss, revealing the darkness that festered beneath the surface. A response to the Rolling Stones, a challenge to prove their own capacity for darkness. The metal seed was sown.

The Surrealists came after him, painting their fractured visions. But Henri Rousseau, long before, was crafting dreams, both of the canvas and the heart.  His *The Dream*, painted in the year nineteen ten, it’s more than a woman at wonder in some painted landscape. It’s Rousseau himself, wrestling with those dreams, the yearnings he held, the hunger for acceptance that gnawed at him. Recognition.  Praise. The love of those who held the keys to the art world, that gilded cage he yearned to enter.  He dreamed it, this prize, and the cost. To conform, to mimic the strokes and styles of the masters, to bend his own vision to fit the mold. Or to stand alone, a singular voice in the clamor, a path carved by his own hand.

This *Dream*, it’s the echo of that struggle. To understand it, you must know the man. Born in Laval, France, in the year of our Lord eighteen forty-four. His father, a man of commerce, a tinsmith, a dealer. Rousseau, he knew none of that world. No formal schooling in the arts, just the tollbooth, the gabelou’s uniform, the steady rhythm of the coin-counting.

Then, the grief came. A wife lost, eight children swallowed by the earth. A daughter, Julia, his only sun. He turned to painting, a refuge, a canvas to wash away the pain. Unlike the sentimentalists who romanticized the peasant, Rousseau, he was one of them.  He painted the world he knew, the dreams of the common man.

His hunger for acceptance was a raw thing. Uneducated, he arrived late to the game, surrounded by titans, men whose names were already whispered in galleries. Matisse, a name that would soon be etched in gold. While Matisse feared banality, Rousseau craved the conventional, the safe harbor of the accepted.

He wanted to be one of them, to be welcomed into the fold. To be more than just a douanier, more than a man who painted dreams. He wanted to be seen, to be heard, to be called an artist.

Many a scholar, many a soul has pondered the kinship, the blood tie, between the things of right and the things of beauty. Truth and grace, hand in hand. Like Keats whispered in his ode,  "Beauty is truth, truth beauty—That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.”  We learn much from books and experience, but these truths, these ethics and aesthetics, they seem to seep in without schooling. Like rumors in the wind, or the scent of blood on the breeze. They are descriptions, not commandments. We study beauty and morality not to build cages, but to understand the wild things within. 

We talk of a masterpiece's worth, dissecting it like a frog on a tabletop, foreground, background, context, all laid bare. But does knowing these things tell you why it sings? Why it haunts you? When someone speaks of a favorite song, a favorite story, you hear it: "There’s just something about it."  Something that sits beyond the bone, beyond the words. 

Like Flannery O'Connor said, a story is a way to say what can't be said plain. A statement falls short.  No matter how we paint the picture, there's a ghost in the room, a whisper in the dark.  Ethics too, has this ghost. Wittgenstein saw it: "It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental." 

This "something," this je ne sais quoi, this is what makes art and morality sing. This is the bridge between them. We feel them, deep in the marrow, in a way we can't quite explain, a truth that sings in the blood.  Literature, it’s the purest form. It lives and breathes our values, our hopes and our sins. It’s a mirror held up to the soul.

The land they call Germany now, a place of strength and unity, a tapestry woven from the high peaks of München down to the brine-kissed shores of Kiel. The thread runs through Köln, a city carved from the Rhine's embrace, and on to Dresden, a stone sentinel on the Elbe. A culture distinct, born of many sources, many tribes.

Germania. The name itself hangs heavy with shadows, a whisper of origins lost to the wind. Scholars and men of history argue its birth, each with a theory to offer. Tacitus, the chronicler, claimed it from a tribe known as the Tungrians, who crossed the Rhine, their swords stained crimson from Gaulish blood (Tacitus, 98).  Caesar, conqueror of Gaul, first penned the word "Germanus" in his grim chronicles of war, a marker to distinguish those he had subdued from those who still held their freedom. He took it from the Gauls themselves, a word to mark the untamed. In his first book, Caesar writes, "The Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (the Gauls) are continually waging war... They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles" (Caesar, 50-40 BC). Others whisper of a spear, the "ger," a weapon of war, or of a Gaelic cry, "garim," meaning to shout, a testament to the Germans' fierce voices. 

Tacitus, in his tome "De Origine et situ Germanorum," penned in the year 98, spoke of a people untouched, unmixed. "I should regard them as aboriginal," he wrote, "and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse." He saw it as a land of harsh beauty, a place where men would not willingly choose to settle unless it was their birthright. "Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?" (Tacitus, 98). 

Rome, with its vast empire, saw Germania as a source of wealth, a place to raid and exploit. They sent their legions, driven by the hunger for gold and glory, but ultimately, they returned to the heart of their domain. The Germanic tribes, they remained, living on the edges of the empire, trading their wares, their skills honed in the crucible of war, serving in the ranks of the Roman legions (Ozment, 2005, pg. 17).

The world below, a tableau of dull brown. I looked down, the scene etched in my mind with the precision of a surgeon's scalpel. Thoughts, like moths, flitted in and out, never settling, never taking root. The mind, a clear and cold pool of observation.

An artist once told me 'draw on the right side of the brain.' He gave me a book, bound in yellowed paper, its title promising secrets - The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain. I, a boy of six, dreamt of drawing. Now, the book lay open, its diagrams a map to a world I could not yet navigate. It spoke of frames, of simplifying the chaos into manageable forms. A bowl of fruit, say, reduced to a simple plane.

But the bowl before me, it held no simple plane. It was a vastness, a chasm of brown.  Picasso in his blue phase, Monet with his greens, the Renaissance masters with their riot of colors - they all had their hues. My hue was brown. This, the beginnings. This, the story. Work in Brown.

My hand, a tool of creation, trembled. Muscles tensed, uncoiled, seeking form. The water, a mirror, reflecting my intent. A swirl, a shudder, a flake breaking away, drifting into the void. Muscles tightened, a spasm, a jolt. The handle of the toilet. A desperate, clawing motion. The brown refuse, glued to the porcelain, mocking me.

Mop in hand, tie choking my throat, I stared. A message, a testament to human waste, left for the cleaners. More flushes, more silence. A hand reached for the wall, the paper trailing like a shroud. A cocoon, a shield.

Standing, bending, dipping my hand into the bowl, a mother into a fiery oven.

The young are dying behind the wheel. A confluence of factors, a dark vector of statistics, points to this grim reality. The learned men at the Institutes say the teen brain, it ain't built for the road. Inexperience, raw and untempered, sits at the heart of it. More than just crashes, it breeds rollovers, speed, and a hunger to run off the blacktop.

And they drive with their kind.  A fact as plain as the sun. The folks down in California, they did some lookin' and found a truth as hard as gravel: the younger the passenger, the higher the chance of a wreck.

States, they've tried to stanch the flow. Provisional licenses, curfews, limits on young company. But these are just patches on a hole in the soul. The young, they're not ready. By all measure, they ain't fit for the weight of the wheel. Even eighteen, a man named Zuckerman says, is too young. He's seen it, studied it.  These young ones, they crave the rush, the edge of the blade.  It's in their blood.

So what's the answer? Delay. Wait till the hunger for the thrill fades, till the recklessness abates. We keep givin' them keys, we'll be drownin' in their blood. The Boomers' young'uns, they're comin' of age. Millions of them, ready to take the wheel.

The fix ain't hard.  Schools can teach, but no child under eighteen, no sir, should be allowed to drive.  A permit, a trial run, maybe, but not the full license. Hours behind the wheel, supervised, logged.  California, they do it right.

It's a simple matter, really. A national standard, a law clear as day. Protect the young, protect us all. Why, it ain't rocket science.

The Library of Congress held a trove of Edison’s early films, flickering ghosts of a vanished age. Fifteen trick films, they called them.  From the year 1895 to 1901, these phantoms played upon the screen, their illusions spun from the threads of edited moments. I watched them, these ghosts of the nascent cinema, their poetics unraveling before me.  Most were bound by the stage, confined within the frame of a proscenium, the camera a silent sentinel, immobile. Long shots, medium shots, these were their domain. Close-ups, the intimacy of a whispered secret, were absent, a world too vast for such scrutiny. One shot, one film, the rule seemed to be. Each a vignette, a fleeting moment captured in time. A minute or less, a blink in eternity.

But there were whispers of rebellion, flickers of change. Some dared to break the mold, to introduce the audacity of multiple shots, stitching together moments to weave a more complex tapestry. The stage remained, the proscenium arch a constant, a boundary that confined the figures within.  They moved side to side, like puppets on a string, never venturing towards or from the lens.  Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel, a film from the year 1900, a good example.  They entered from the right, their forms swallowed by the darkness, then reappeared, moving back and forth, bound to the stage's confines. The camera, a watchful eye, never followed.

The trick films were echoes of the theatre, of vaudeville’s magic and illusion. The audience, like spectators in a grand hall, saw the whole, framed by the proscenium's embrace.  A single “shot” could be a symphony of moments, joined invisibly to create the illusion of apparition, of disappearing acts. Look closely at The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots, one of the earliest of these phantoms. The severed “head” appears in a moment, a single shot, but a closer inspection reveals the stitching, the joining of moments, the illusion carefully constructed.

John Taylor of Caroline, a man of the soil, was a firebrand for Republicanism. Though his life was bound to the rhythm of the fields, that same life, brief as it was in the halls of power, forged a man known for his unwavering convictions. Freedom was the seed he tended, both in the realm of man and in the machinations of government. His faith in the agrarian way was the bedrock of his convictions, shaping his pronouncements on sovereignty, on the very nature of the Constitution, on the scales of justice.

He saw in the new nation a chance to build something true, unburdened by the ghosts of ancient customs.  The ground was fertile, unmarred, ready to bear the fruit of self-government.  He held fast to the natural rights of man, a creed as immutable as the laws of nature itself. He saw them as a chain, indivisible, fragile.  If one link was broken, the whole would fray and weaken. These rights, he argued, must be kept beyond the reach of man's own designs, for they were the very essence of his being. He scoffed at the notion of a "state of nature," where the strong preyed on the weak, where cunning was a shield against the brute force of the world.  Civilization, he believed, demanded a higher order.

To build this ideal, Taylor envisioned a government that understood the duality of human nature.  Good and evil resided within each man, a constant struggle.  He held fast to this duality, a rigid moral compass guiding his every thought.  Government, he argued, could not escape the imperfections of its creators.  "As government is exercised by man," he wrote, "all its virtues and vices must be human."  He saw good principles in the protection of private property, in the nurturing of the land, in the curbing of unchecked ambition.  A government founded on these principles, he believed, would function justly, despite the inevitable flaws of its administrators, for they would be swayed by the twin demons of avarice and self-interest.

Self-interest, he argued, was the engine that drove men, but it was only when it festered, when it bent the human heart towards the destruction of the common good, that it became a scourge.  A good government, he believed, was necessary to contain this inherent darkness, to act as a watchful sentinel against the creeping corruption of power.

Like many of his Republican brethren, Taylor was a champion of strict construction.  He envisioned a Federal government limited in scope, its powers confined to the explicit pronouncements of the Constitution.  He saw an expansive government as a breeding ground for tyranny, a bottomless pit of expense and corruption.  Yet, he warned against a rigid, literal interpretation, for it could be a path to ruin.  He sought a deeper understanding, a grasp of the intent of the framers, a respect for the spirit behind the words.  And he saw the Declaration of Independence as the true charter of the nation, a testament to the sovereignty of the states, a beacon of liberty in a world yearning for freedom.

The graph, Figure 17, showed a sudden drop in the commuter logs come the third month. A dispiriting sight. The reasons, hard to say. Winter had settled on the New England campus, a chill in the air that kept folks off bikes and out of the cold. December, the semester's end, found everyone consumed: papers due, grades looming. The log, a forgotten thing. And then came the holidays, a month-long break, campus emptied, no need to tread the paths. Classes resumed in late January, yet the logs remained scarce. 

The drop in February, that was a mystery. Projects, they run hot at first, then cool. A natural thing. So we tried to stoke the fire. Carpool Challenge Week in March, a blitz of prizes and pleas. It worked. The logs climbed. 

But the lesson was clear: keeping a project alive, that's a fight. The ebb and flow of semester breaks, the slow creep of indifference, these are enemies to be reckoned with.

Another foe: the car. A freedom, a comfort, woven into the fabric of this country. To win folks away, you need more than good intentions.  

We offered prizes, gift certificates to cafes, shops, a massage here and there. Maybe something bigger would have helped - a bike, a hybrid car, even an electric one.  The prizes, they stayed the same. But what if they had grown? A bike announced in December, a hybrid in January. Maybe then, the logs wouldn't have dwindled.

The Exchange Traded Fund. A thing of metal and paper, a security they say, designed to mimic the dance of the market. A basket of holdings, an index, a commodity, all bound together and traded like the single stock it ain’t.  It offers the broad stroke of the index fund, they say, but with the tools of the individual - shorting, margin, all the tricks of the trade at your fingertips, all for a fraction of the cost.  

But there’s a price, always a price.  Each trade, a commission paid, like a toll on the road to riches. And even with these supposed benefits, the question hangs heavy: does the diversification truly exist? Does it hold true, or is it a phantom, a whisper in the wind?

We’ll look at this IHF, a creature of the market, and dissect its top ten holdings, the beasts that make up its flesh and blood.  These ten, they account for a good portion of the whole, 63.58% they claim. We’ll see if they truly represent the creature, if they can stand on their own, if they offer a path to profit that surpasses the sum of its parts.

We’ll measure their return, their beta, these metrics of risk and reward. And we’ll see if a portfolio built from these same ten, in the same proportions, can beat the creature itself. Can it offer a higher return, a lower risk?  

The numbers will tell the tale, or at least they’ll offer a glimpse into the shadows.

The land of dreams, so Poe called it.  One of his better poems, he claimed. In "Dream-Land," he casts a word, "Thulé," into the verses, a word traced back by Mabbott to the lips of Virgil. Virgil, speaking of an island north of Britain, a place the Greeks held as the edge of knowing.  Virgil used it, that's certain. But there's a newer source, one to which credit must be given. Poe, he was drawn to the words of the Germans. 

This reference, it speaks to Poe's familiarity with Goethe's own dark musings. Karl J. Arndt, in his book "Poe’s Politian and Goethe’s Mignon," he draws a line between their words, suggests Poe was mimicking the master. 

The Oxford Companion to English Literature, it tells us of Goethe, celebrated writer of the tragic drama "Faust," a work split into two parts, the first in 1808, the second with the author's own passing in 1832. Within the second part, a short poem, "The King of Thulé." A king grieving his wife, who offered him a goblet as a gift, now drinks deeply and weeps. He decides his time has come and gives his possessions to his children, save for the goblet.  He walks to a precipice, casts the goblet into the sea, closes his eyes, and falls. The King of Thulé, his demeanor, his very being, mirrored in the shadowy figure of Poe's "Dream-Land."  A dark reflection, perhaps, of Poe's own loss and his solace in drink.

Faust, it also found its way onto the stage, woven into a romantic drama by H.P. Grattan in 1842, less than a year before Poe himself used the term "Thulé" in "The Pit and the Pendulum."

Twice Poe summons "Thulé" in his own writings. Once he speaks of "ultma Thule" in "The Pit and the Pendulum," but in "Dream-Land" it sits, bookends to the poem.  "The King of Thulé" and "Dream-Land," they stand as companions, their verses echoing one another. In "Dream-Land," the speaker walks into that bleak landscape, haunted by the ghosts of friends departed. He sees a world drained of color, a world of shadows.  These are the echoes of "The King of Thulé," a man consumed by grief, a king lost in the darkness following his wife's death. The entire poem, it reads as if the speaker has stepped into Goethe's own lament.

Goethe, a giant in literature, a figure Poe would have known, if for no other reason than his admiration for Tennyson.   Poe once said, when asked of Tennyson, “I have read his poetry with the utmost interest….”

And beyond that connection, Poe would have encountered Goethe's works in the many reproductions that were blossoming in those years.

The law in this sun-bleached state says a man might find redress, might find justice, if he were to fall, a victim to the slick treachery of spilled applesauce. The question then becomes, could this man, this Palmer,  win more than just the coin for his hurt? Could he wrest from the pockets of the store, the D&D, a sum meant as punishment? 

A judge, he might not be quick to dismiss this claim. Palmer must show the manager, Martin, acted not merely carelessly, but with a deliberate indifference, a cold heart. The law speaks of "willful and conscious disregard" -  a man who knows the danger and chooses to ignore it. And "despicable" too, it must be, this conduct.

Palmer will say Martin knew the danger. Six times before, men and women had stumbled, fallen, victim to the same treacherous slickness.  Six times, and still Martin, he lingered over his dinner, ignoring the pleas of his own men. 

On that day, the thirteenth of October, the air heavy with the scent of apples and something else, something darker,  Wayne told Martin of the spill. Martin, he mumbled about his dinner, about the complaints of men, as if they were bothersome flies. Haddigan, another, she too brought word of the danger. Same answer, same disinterest. And then, at half past five, Palmer, she slipped.  A broken back. A shattered life.

The law in this land, it speaks of malice, of oppression, of a disregard for the safety of others. A cold disregard, a willful one.  Will the court find it here? Will they see the malice in Martin's indifference?

Four years gone. A semester at CBC, dust swirling in the air like desert sand. Islam. The word hung heavy in the classroom, a question mark echoing in the faces of the young. Was it a religion of peace or a fist raised in the name of God? A question that gnawed then, even more so now. 

The world spun its kaleidoscope. After the smoke cleared, the media shifted, a pendulum swinging from suspicion to an acceptance bordering on worship. Could a man like Obama, a name whispered with both reverence and fear, a name touched by the shadow of Islam, have ever risen to the highest office? Unthinkable in the before-time.

The Prophet's story, a tapestry woven with threads of history and faith, intrigued me. I'd heard tales of a warrior, a conqueror who carved a path with the edge of his sword, forcing men to kneel before Allah. But this biography painted a different picture, a martyr misunderstood, a man who humbled himself before the gaze of the world.  And slowly, like moths drawn to a flickering flame, they came, drawn to the light of his words.

The echoes of Jesus resonated in the miracle tales, the loaves and fishes multiplied, the water turned to wine. But here, the shepherd offered mutton and milk, a simple feast for forty men. A subtle shift, a whisper of an alternative.  Did they seek to elevate him, to paint him as a prophet who needed no proof, only the quiet hum of truth? A silent theft, a shadow play cast upon the life of Christ.

And the stories, whispered from man to man, each a layer of gauze obscuring the truth.  A chain of witnesses, each link a fading memory. Did this lend credence or cast doubt?  Was this the mark of truth, or the echo of a carefully crafted narrative?

The most unsettling thing, the thing that gnawed at the edges of my mind, was the attempt to elevate Muhammad. To paint him as a gentle shepherd, a sage, a man of peace. A man who, history whispered, was forged in the fire of conquest. Could those who followed him truly know the truth, the man behind the myth?

The man called Jesus. His words. His way.  Left behind, they were, in the dust of his passing.  Christianity, a thing of slow, inexorable change, drifted from its moorings.  The world, it writhes and twists, ever forward, ever changing.  The old ways cling, stubborn as weeds, but their hold weakens.  A yearning will bloom, a hunger in the hearts of men. A seeking after the root, the source, the wellspring before the waters ran thick with dogma.  Decades, centuries perhaps, but the tide will turn. Backwards.  Layer by layer, the accretions will fall away, until only the bare bones remain.  The bones of Jesus. The bones of God's word as he spoke it.  A vast movement, a tide of souls returning to the shore.  

The church, the institution, it will endure.  But the things within, the tangled vines of belief, will be pruned.  Uniformity will rise from the ashes of diversity.  One faith, one voice.  History, it is a river, ever flowing, ever changing course.  Persecution to power, from shackles to leadership, the wheel turns.  Now it turns again, towards the source.  Towards Jesus.   

The key lies in the words.  Not as stone tablets, immutable and cold, but as whispered truths, echoes of a timeless well.  

Before Jesus, before the man, there was the seed.  Judaism.  Monotheism, a single God, a single truth.  The scriptures, a wellspring of ancient wisdom.  Divisions within, yes. Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots.  But a unity of core belief.  The foundation.

The muck of man. That's what Sinclair lays bare in *The Jungle*. Greed, a sickness, it consumes them all, these men with their factories and their dreams of empires. They build their towers of brick and steel, spitting smoke into the belly of the sky, heedless of the blight it brings. The river of their industry runs black, poisoned with the waste of their hunger.  They see no man, no beast, only profit. 

Their hands, stained with the sweat and blood of the working man, count only the coins. Loyalty? Decency?  Faded words in the clang and clatter of the gears. Here, a man is a cog, a replaceable part in their machine. Hours bleed into days, days into years. A layoff, a whisper on the wind, and a family left to starve.  No law to shield them, no hand to pull them from the mire.

Sinclair paints a picture of a hell on earth, a Packingtown choked by its own ambition. The workers, chained not by iron but by circumstance, are but ghosts in a city of shadows. They toil, they bleed, they die, their cries swallowed by the roar of industry.  He calls them slaves, and the word rings true, for what is man but a slave to his own desires, a slave to the system that grinds him down?

The writer, he crafts worlds with language.  Shapes the reader's heart with the words he chooses. Some paths are truer than others. Fitzgerald, he knew this. In *The Great Gatsby*, he spins a tapestry of meaning, threads of gold and green, white and gray, red and pink. He builds a language of symbol, a whispers of what lies beneath. And the colors, they sing a song of longing and decay.

Fitzgerald paints white and gray, not as they are, but as they become.  White, a brittle purity, the sheen of something higher. Gray, the dust of time, the fading of dreams. It hangs in the air from the first page. Daisy, Jordan, they are cloaked in white.  Nick, he wears white flannels to Gatsby's party, a white shirt, a ghost in the throng.  And the only time the white fades, it's in the gaudy hues of Gatsby's hollow revelry.

He paints the world in shades of meaning. The canyons of the city, white chasms. Names on a timetable, gray, lost in the churn.  Catherine's apartment, a white shard in a city of white.  Even the child of the railroad, a whisper of gray.  And the old man selling dogs, his face weathered, his soul gray. 

And then he uses it.  He uses white and gray to define Daisy.  After a long silence, she reappears, a shimmer of white. A little white roadster, a ghost in the summer heat.  She is no longer a woman, but a longing, a phantom of Gatsby's desire.  The haze of her fur collar, gray, a veil over her true self.  White again, before the confrontation, a spectral figure in the gathering storm.

The sun beat down on San Diego County, baking the soil and coaxing life from the earth. A land of plenty, they called it. Tomatoes fattened on the vine, citrus trees hung heavy with fruit, and leafy greens unfurled in the gentle breeze. Squash, broccoli, herbs, peaches, lemons, berries, honey, peppers – the bounty was vast.  And there were those who sought to cultivate it with a touch lighter than the hand of industry.

Word had spread of a different kind of farm, one that eschewed the chemical kiss of progress for the slow, patient rhythm of nature.  Organic, they called it. Community Supported Agriculture, a network of folks willing to pay a premium for a slice of the earth's honest gift. Waiting lists stretched long, a testament to the yearning for something more, something real.

Eggs laid by hens roaming free, milk drawn from cows grazing on sun-drenched pastures, these were the staples of a simpler time, a time when man walked more lightly on the land. Farms became sanctuaries, offering more than just sustenance. Trails wound through fields of ripening vegetables, inviting weary souls to escape the city's clamor. Birdsong filled the air, a chorus of life undisturbed by the hum of machinery.

This, they believed, was the way forward. A way to heal the land, to nourish the body and the soul, and to build a future where man and nature could exist in harmony.

But the path wasn't easy. Organic farming demanded more, a constant vigilance against pests and weeds, a tireless nurturing of the soil.  The yields were often less, the costs higher. Yet, the reward was more than just a profit. It was the satisfaction of knowing that one was part of something larger, something enduring. 

The land itself held secrets, whispered tales of ancient peoples who had walked these paths before. Cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers had come and gone, leaving their mark on the landscape.  Now, a new chapter was about to begin. A chapter marked by the promise of a future where the earth's bounty could once again be shared with all who sought it.

Culture. A word that hangs heavy, a shroud. A ghost whispering in the halls of men. What it is, what it ain't, a riddle wrapped in a riddle.  Not a single thing, not a uniform fabric. To say all Russians are stubborn, all Japanese accommodating, that's a lie told by fools. It's the shadows and the silences that matter, the way a culture breathes, the way it bleeds. A stranger comes to a foreign land, and he sees it through the lens of his own experience. Comparisons bloom like weeds.

To understand another, you gotta dig deep. History, prejudices, the roots that bind them. You can't judge, you can't change. You can only accept. The boundaries are set. Especially at the table, where men trade goods and souls.  A weaker hand, a foreign tongue - respect for the way things are, that's your only shield.

But culture ain't confined to borders. It lives in the walls of a house, in the steel and glass cages we call companies. Some grind men down, some let them breathe. Dress codes, the way words are strung together, the way tasks are passed from hand to hand - these are the whispers of a company's soul.  Look at America, a land of contradictions, where even within the same city, the air can taste different.

Values. That's the heart of it. Why a man acts, why he flinches, why he bargains hard. To save face, to keep the peace, that's one culture. To strike a blow, to claim victory, that's another. Before you sit across from a man, you gotta know his why.

But the deepest knowledge comes from the man himself.  A name, a story, a glimpse into the soul. That's what makes the table sing. That's what makes a deal worthwhile.

The fool's words echoed in the mind: there is no God. A whisper from the Psalms, a seed planted by the hand of the ancients. Anselm, that seeker of truth, took those words and twisted them, spun them into a web to catch the Almighty. But Aquinas, the man of reason, he scoffed at such shadows. He sought proof in the dust and the light, in the motion and the stillness.

Two men, two roads, both converging on the same destination: the face of the Creator. But their journeys were as different as fire and ice. Anselm, he looked inward, into the dark chambers of the soul. He claimed that God resided there, a hidden truth revealed only to those who dared to seek. Faith, he called it, a leap into the void.  

Aquinas, he looked outward, at the world laid bare before him. He saw the gears turning, the cause and effect, the echo of design in the chaos. He spoke of logic, of proof. Five arguments, he laid them out, each a stone in a wall built against doubt.

But do these walls hold? Does faith truly illuminate the darkness, or does it merely create an illusion of light? And can reason, cold and calculating, ever truly grasp the Divine? The answer, like God himself, remains elusive.

The prince born into the world sometime in the dark half-life of the fifth century, before the counting of Christ, would one day be known as Buddha. He cast off the world, seeking solace in the silence. His words, carried on the wind, took root and blossomed into Buddhism, a faith as old as the mountains themselves. Theravada, the oldest branch, still clings to the bones of his teachings, though the flesh has changed. 

This is seen in Sri Lanka, a land where the monks still perform the water-cutting ceremony, a rite as ancient as the island's heart, though Buddha himself spoke nothing of such things. The changes run deep, from the painted faces of the faithful to the very essence of their salvation. Both the cloistered and the lay, bound by the same thread of faith, have had to bend the doctrines to fit the shape of a changing world. 

To understand this we must speak in riddles, for there are forces at play both within and without the fold. Internal forces, born of the heart of the Buddhasasana, monastic or lay, they shape the faith from within. External forces, from those who do not tread the same path, come bearing gifts or shadows. Hostile forces, they seek to wound the heart of the faith, fueled by misunderstanding and malice. Benign forces, they may mean no harm, yet their touch can soothe or scar. 

We speak first of the core, the bedrock of Theravada. Refuge is found in the triple gem: the Buddha, the Dhamma, the Sangha. The Dhamma, the teachings, slumber in the three baskets: the Suttas, the Vinaya, and the Abhidhamma. The Suttas contain the words of the Buddha, the Vinaya the rules of conduct, and the Abhidhamma, the secrets of the mind, where concepts like Anatta – no self – and Dukkha – the eternal ache of being – find their dwelling. Only by understanding these truths, the impermanence of all things, can one escape the wheel of Sansara, the endless cycle of birth and death.  

With Sansara, the serpent of desire, lobha, the viper of hatred, dosa, and the fog of delusion, moha, will finally be laid to rest. In the Vinaya, the path is laid out, the rules for living, five for the lay and many more for those who walk the monastic road.  

But the heart of it all, the pivot on which the world turns, is the Four Noble Truths. First, Dukkha, the truth of suffering. Second, that craving is the root of suffering. Third, that this suffering can be overcome. Fourth, that the path to overcome suffering is the Eightfold Path.

The borderlands between the two republics, America and Mexico, had known a long and bitter feud. Fifty-seven years it stretched, from the year '36 to the turn of the century, a time when rifle smoke and red blood stained the earth. The War, they called it, a war that saw the young and hungry nation carve out its dominion westward, swallowing Texas and the sun-baked lands of the Southwest. It was a war born of clashing creeds, a struggle between the old world and the new, between the ways of the Cross and the ways of the frontier.  

Before the bells of war tolled, there were skirmishes, raids, whispers of discontent. The men on both sides, fueled by a hunger for land and a thirst for power, found themselves locked in a dance of violence, a macabre waltz that echoed through the canyons and deserts.

The old grudges, born of the Spanish and English, lingered like a bad smell in the air. A shadow cast by the past, it darkened the path to understanding. The borderlands, a place of both promise and peril, became a stage for this age-old drama.

And as the years wore on, the rivalry waned, not with a bang but a whimper. Mexico, bound by necessity, found itself tethered to the American eagle. The hunger for land had been replaced by a hunger for profit, and the shadow of war receded into the dust.

Fifteen years gone. Snatched by an illness, a shadow thing I didn't know existed. I was a nurse then, tending to the sick and weary. A choice made out of need, a yearning for the kind of safety that had eluded me as a child.  "Always a job, people always ailing," they'd say.  A mantra to ease the ache of uncertainty. But the science, the words, that was the pull, a yearning for knowledge. Still, the safe harbor of nursing beckoned.

Now, at forty-six, alone, pockets bare, the sickness had taken hold. Fifteen years on that thin thread of Social Security, and nothing left to call my own.  A day-to-day struggle, a gnawing fear that claws at the edges of security, safety, even self-worth. Nothing certain anymore, yet one thing rings true: I wouldn't have weathered this storm without the hands that pulled me up, the love and solace of family and friends.  A stark reminder, when the world turns dark, how little strength we truly possess.

Life, it throws its punches. Big and small, they come without warning. No wall can hold back the tide. Preparedness is a virtue, yes, but some things are beyond the reach of even the sturdiest shelter.

The talk of rugged individualism, of self-reliance, it echoes through the halls of power. But the bones of this nation weren't built on isolation. They were forged in the fires of compassion, in the shared burdens and the lifting hands of neighbors. Those pioneers, they crossed the vast plains not by going it alone, but by the strength of their shared purpose.

So yes, be ready. Stock your shelves, gather your supplies.  Candles, flints, canned goods, water.  A fire in the belly, a fire in the hearth. But while you prepare for the storm, remember the faces around you. The ones who stand beside you, the ones who might need your hand. That, too, is a kind of preparation.

The why of it, the how of it, this shaping of life. What binds it, what bends it? D'Arcy Thompson, back in '17, he said the zoologist barely dreamt of speaking of life in numbers. The words still ring true. But now, they try. They try to mimic the dance of the shell, the slow build of the mollusk, with equations and lines. Raup and Stanley, they took a crack at it, back in '81, with their models of belly-housing. Our work, it follows that path. We look at *Prunum*, the spiral-shelled kind, and ask how the numbers tell the story. We use the ghosts of shells, captured in X-ray, to tease out the measure of their form. We feed these bones of data into CerioShell, Stone's program, and watch the forms shift, grow, change. We want to know what the limits are, the boundaries of possibility. What can a shell become? And how does it become it? This, we try to piece together, with the whispers of the shell and the language of the machine. 

A shell, it's a journey through time and space, a tube winding, turning, ever-spiraling. Each turn, a whorl, a whisper of the past, clinging to the imaginary line of the columella, the heart of the spiral. The whorls grow, some faster, some slower, separated by sutures, fine lines marking the passage of time. The last whorl, the body whorl, the one holding the flesh, the one we see first. The rest, the spire, a record of the journey before. The apex, the tip of the spire, the beginning. The base, the end, the mouth of the world. And through it all, the aperture, the opening, the breath of the creature.

We look at the shell from every angle, apical, basal, apertural, abapertural. The usual way, the shell face tilted towards us, the apex reaching towards the heavens. 

Counting the whorls, it's like tracing the steps of a ghost. Start at the apex, the first suture, a line dividing the past from the present. Count the whorls from there, each one a quarter of a story.

The shell, it's a series of apertures, a path through time and space, each whorl a marker, a place where the creature touched the world. We chart this path, the center of each aperture, the radius, the dimensions of its world. We make it speak in numbers, in equations. And with these numbers, we can change it, twist it, make it new.

The bones of the infant and the child.  In Indonesia they lay still for a decade, these numbers.  The country, it crawls toward the sunlight of those distant goals, the Millennium promises of water and clean earth. But the mothers and the young, their fate hangs by a thread. The road to salvation by 2015 is long and shadowed. 

The reasons for this failing, they whisper in the wind.  A broken system, not a program, demands fixing.  

They speak of midwives, skilled in the old ways, tending the births of seventy-two percent of the children.  But skill is a hollow word when the storm breaks, when the mother bleeds.  The old ways cannot mend what the modern age can.  And the children, the young ones, they wither from the unseen demons of diarrhea.  Forgotten in the afterbirth, the mothers too, abandoned by the hand of care.  

The knife, the cold steel of the surgeon's blade, it finds its mark in the cities, seven percent.  But in the fields, where the sun bleeds red, it's a mere two.  A chasm opens between the haves and the have-nots, a wound in the fabric of the land.  The rich, they feast on health, the poor, they starve.  A gulf of twenty-seven percent, a stark reminder of the price of poverty.

Now the question hangs, a shadow in the air:  programs or a system?  The quick fix, the targeted blow, it beckons.  But it's a siren song, luring them to shallow waters.  The money flows, it dries the wells of other fields, leaving only dust and despair.  The body, it is not a collection of parts, but a whole, a singular entity.  The programs, they are splintered shards, failing to see the truth.

The Victorian age. A time of lace and lords, of detail spun fine as cobwebs and manners stiff as starched collars. Yet even in that gilded cage, certain stories took flight, wings clipped but still beating, stories that dared to veer from the gilded path.

Take *Oliver Twist*, for instance, or *Wuthering Heights*. Both whisper of shadows, of things unseen that claw at the edges of reason.  They are novels of mystery,  of the bizarre blooming in the heart of the ordinary. This is what gives them their edge, their bite. The characters, trapped within their own labyrinthine worlds, writhe beneath the surface. Their desires, their fears, they are laid bare, exposed like raw nerves.

Dickens, he knew how to burrow into the mind, how to pull out the gristle and sinew of a soul. This passage, a glimpse into Oliver's fractured consciousness:


"And now, hosts of bewildering and confusing ideas came crowding on his mind. He seemed to be still walking between Sikes and Crackit, who were angrily disputing: for the very words they said, sounded in his ears; and when he caught his own attention, … he found that he was talking to them…. Suddenly he started back at the report of fire arms; and there rose into the air loud cries and shouts; lights gleamed before his eyes, and all was noise and tumult, as some unseen hand bore him hurriedly away. Through all these rapid visions, there ran an undefined, uneasy consciousness of pain, which weared and tormented him incessantly.” 


(Dickens, 220)

He's adrift, lost in a sea of pain and confusion. The line between reality and nightmare blurs, the shooting, the faces of Sikes and Crackit, all swirling together in a maelstrom of terror. It's a potent image, the boy helpless, a puppet in the hands of fate. This is the heart of the mystery, the question that gnaws at the soul: who is pulling the strings?

The same thread, this dance with the unseen, runs through *Wuthering Heights*. Dreams bleed into reality, and the past, like a ghost, lingers in the shadows. But here, the mystery is more complex, more rooted in the characters themselves.

They are creatures of passion, consumed by dark desires, driven by a hunger that can never be satiated.  Theirs is a world of secrets, of forbidden love, and of revenge that echoes through generations.  They are trapped, not just by circumstance, but by their own tormented souls.

Two years gone now. Worked the after-school shift, tutoring the young ones. English and reading, that's where I found my footing.  A boy, Adrian, maybe third or fourth grade, came to me. Couldn't read a lick. Strange, it was. Some letters, he'd pronounce clear as a bell, others, like they were foreign. He spoke English good as any, but reading, it was a wall. Latino, I reckoned, though the boy spoke no Spanish to my ears. We wrestled with it, day after day, till one afternoon, the boy's mother walked in. Didn't speak a word of English. Just Spanish. Me, barely a whisper of the tongue myself. But then, it hit me. Like a load of bricks. The boy, he could read fine.  He just didn't know the English letters. Never did figure if it helped him much, though I hope he's doing alright.

That's the thing about language, see. It ain't always plain as day. Even for a boy who speaks it smooth, reading, it can be a birth-giving ache.  California's got a problem, a wall of tongues. What to do about it? Adrian, he needed simple things: English reading, the alphabet, the sounds. But the kids who barely speak it, now that's a different beast. No single answer fits. Dual language, immersion, tutors, ESL. Each one a piece of the puzzle, but not the whole. 

Dual language, that's a good start. Not just for the Spanish-speakers, mind you, but for all.  Those kids in two-way programs, they outpace their peers.  Folks fear it, say it's a waste, that the majority won't see a dime's worth.  But that's a lie. Make it the rule, not the exception, and everyone benefits. But how?  We ain't gonna make every teacher bilingual, are we? Unreasonable, that is.  But what if we had helpers, tutors, folks who spoke both tongues, to lend a hand?

The world whispers of something vast, something beyond reckoning. A Presence. Some are ushered into pews, others into temples, still others left to grapple with it alone. Faith, a heirloom passed down, accepted or cast aside. Some hold tight to a creed, only to see it crumble in the face of the howling void.  We are adrift, each a lone vessel searching for a beacon in the dark. A compass in the chaos.

"A cardinal," he'd said, thin lips barely moving, eyes fixed on the rain drumming a mournful rhythm on the tin roof.  We sat on the porch, smoke curling from our cigarettes, the air thick with the smell of wet earth and decay. The gutters overflowed, drowning the wilted blooms along the edge of the boards. He stared out at the gray world, a haunted look in his eyes, lost in some half-remembered ache. He'd grown gaunt, his clothes hanging loose on his frame. His hair, once a thick thatch, now sparse, like the brushstrokes of a fading memory. He didn't meet my gaze, and I felt a cold knot in my chest. A fear I couldn't name, a fear of saying the words that would make it real, the words that would seal the bargain. So I sat beside him, drew closer, and watched the rain fall, swallowed by the twilight.

He went in December, five days after my twenty-second year. The treatments, the poison they pumped into him, had only bought him a few more months. Months of pain. What good was that? I thought, alone in the darkness, no prayers on my tongue. If God existed, he'd long since turned his back.

I wouldn't watch him go. I couldn't bear to see the life that birthed me fade into the void. I would remember him as he lived, not as he died. I knew him better than they did. Better than his own kin. He wouldn't have wanted me there, a silent witness to his surrender.  I curled in the bed, a small, shivering thing, waiting for the word.

No word came.

The Gothic, Watt called it an oxymoron. "Old-New." A contradiction writ large. Praised and damned, dismissed as shallow and hailed for its dreadful grandeur.  Walpole, the first to christen it, saw the Gothic in the clash of the ancient and the modern. He wove it into the fabric of "The Castle of Otranto," a tapestry of theatricality and nature's mimicry, a story born of shadows and moonlight.  

 Even then, "Gothic" was a word tossed about, a misnomer for a thousand things, past and present, a relic of a time deemed archaic. But in Walpole's hands, the ancient and the new found a strange harmony. The Gothic novel, with its intimate gaze into the soul, a window into the heart of man, it endured.  

Chivalry, that fading dream of knighthood, pulsed at the heart of it all. The training, the code, the idealized knight, a beacon in a world perceived as lacking its virtues.  The Gothic, in its yearning for a lost age, romanticized the past, a yearning for a purity that seemed to have vanished. 

Walpole, writing amidst the turmoil of his time, saw the decay, the moral rot that threatened to consume the present. He saw it in Frederic, a prince, a survivor of tragedy, a figure cloaked in chivalric ideals, a man who embodied the virtues they had lost. A ghost of nobility in a world grown dark.  

The description of him, a litany of chivalric tropes, a prince, a victim, a warrior marked by loss. The gallant knight, exaggerated, pushed to the edge of excess, a harbinger of the dark theatricality to come.

The flow.  It starts with the want. The call from the customer, a whisper in the wind.  Then the chase. For the raw stuff, the sinew and bone of the thing. The making. The forging. The sending out. This they call supply chain management. A term coined by a man named Oliver, back in the year 1982.  He spoke of planning, of control, of keeping the gears oiled and turning to satisfy the hunger of the wanting.

Six things hold it together. Production, the heart of it all. Supply, the veins that feed the beast. Inventory, the marrow. Location, the bones. Transportation, the movement. And information, the whisper that guides the hand.

Producers, they stand at the forge. They know what the people crave. They look to the market, a vast and shifting landscape, and read the signs. What will sell? How much? Where will it be born? These are the questions that drive them.

They choose the ground, the place where metal melts and shapes take form. They build the machines, and train the hands that wield them. Every detail a prayer, every bolt a hope. For if the steps are not taken in order, if the rhythm falters, the whole damn thing can collapse.

Take Wal-Mart, for instance. Or Target. They have plans for everything. A blueprint for every action, every movement. Even the way a man ties his shoes. For in this world, order is everything.

And then there's supply. The choice of who will feed the fire. Will it be done in-house, or will the work be cast out, sent to others? The manager weighs the options, seeking velocity. The speed of creation, the agility to adapt, the cost of it all.

For in the end, it's all about the flow. A river of goods, driven by the needs of men.

The sign hung crooked, a rasping testament to a truth too stark for comfort.  "Hitler is alive in Burma," it said. Ellen Page, face pale under the glare of the streetlights, stood clutching it. Burma, that land of jade and shadows, ruled by iron fists since '62, a coup's dark echo lingering still. Monks, robed in saffron, had dared to rise, a tide of yellow against the grey. The Saffron Revolution they called it, a whisper of hope choked by the steel of the junta.  

The air, thick with the scent of jasmine and fear, had tasted of violence. Monasteries, once sanctuaries, lay desecrated, their silence broken only by the ghosts of prayer. A Japanese lensman, Nagai, had seen too much, his camera a silent witness to the junta's wrath. A bullet silenced his voice, a stark footnote to the reign of terror.  

Thirteen, they said. The official count. A lie, whispered by the wind, carried on the backs of refugees. Colonel Win, a broken man, a ghost of the army he'd known, spoke of thousands swallowed by the earth. It was a song as old as time, this hunger for power, this thirst to crush dissent underfoot. Caesar, with his legions, the Japanese emperor, a god-king, and Bush, whispered to by Haggard, the shepherd of fools. A tapestry woven with threads of blood, stained by the hands of men who sought dominion. 

Tiananmen Square, a sea of bodies crushed beneath the iron fist of the state. The whispers of 2,000, 3,000, lost in the official silence.  Rwanda, a genocide painted in the crimson of hate, where neighbor turned on neighbor, fueled by the poison of fear.  And Hitler's Germany, a specter haunting the world, a testament to the darkness that can consume a nation.

The sign sagged, a burden on Page's shoulders.  A truth too heavy to bear, a truth that refused to be silenced. Burma. A land where history repeats, a land where hope flickers like a dying ember in the wind.

Duke Ellington's shadow stretches long across the jazz landscape. It’s a shadow cast by longevity, by the hand of a man who could mold his orchestra, coax brilliance from its members. Though his own touch on the piano sometimes fades into the background of his compositions, his voice as a composer rings clear. He wove intricate tapestries of sound, rich and complex, that gave every man in his band the space to sing. He built frameworks where solos could breathe, wrote phrases that snagged on the ear, and drew out the particular fire in each player.  He shaped the tone of the whole, birthing sounds that were both coherent and wild, unique to each piece. This mastery of individual voice, and the way those voices bled into a collective whole, brought forth some of the most striking, the most enduring music jazz has ever known. 

The Grove, in its dusty tome, speaks of Ellington's sound, his innovation. It cites "Creole Love Call," a song where the voice itself is made an instrument, a thread woven through his whole career.  This, an early example, shows how he used the voice for texture, for color, unbound by the chains of words. "Creole Love Call" also whispers of his skill in letting the soloists bloom. It’s a slow, deliberate blues, twelve bars long, six choruses unfolding like a sigh.

The first chorus, a call and response, voice and reeds, starts smooth, melodic, then roughens, a growl rising in the throat. The second, a muted trumpet solo, a winding path through the melody, blue notes stretching like shadows. The third, a clarinet like a bird soaring, high and sweet, backed by a piano that whispers in a syncopated dance. The fourth, the whole band echoing the first chorus, brass and reeds answering, a conversation in sound. The fifth, the climax, reeds calling, voices high and urgent, brass and rhythm holding back, a stop-time beat like a held breath. The sixth, back to the first, voice and reeds, but now the voice takes on that growl, a solo instrument in its own right. And then, a brief tag, a vocal run, a trombone with a dissonant sigh, a final whisper.

This use of voice, this coloring of sound, it’s a thread running through his work. "Hot and Bothered," recorded a year later, shows him weaving tight orchestration with an ear for tone. A call and response, "Bubber" Miley's muted trumpet talking to Baby Cox's scat, the voice a melody, the trumpet a rhythm, a rich tapestry. "It Don't Mean a Thing (If It Ain't Got That Swing)," and Joe "Tricky Sam" Nanton, a constant in Ellington's world, introduces the melody on a muted trombone, a sound both mournful and joyous.

The wanting had always been there. A hunger that gnawed. Not for things, not at first. It started in the liminal space between girl and woman, when the world was just beginning to close in.  Fourteen, fifteen, sixteen.  Years bled into one another, the wanting sharpening, taking on a new form.  She sought connection, a hand in hers, a gaze that lingered.  But boys, they were like moths drawn to her flame, clumsy and eager, but never quite right. She watched them flit about, these suitors, and wondered at their blindness.  What was it she lacked, this strange emptiness that echoed in her chest? Theories whispered in the back of her mind, shadows skittering across the cavern of her soul, but none offered a satisfying answer.

The house was usually a place of quiet. Her parents, they moved through the world like ghosts, their voices low murmurs in the stillness. Arguments were rare, a ghost story told only in hushed tones.  The only discord came when she, a whirlwind of energy, clashed against their gentle currents.  She was a storm in a teacup, a bright spark in their quiet lives.

But today, the air hung heavy. A dissonance crackled in the air. She moved from room to room, searching for solace, when a scream tore through the quiet. Her mother’s voice, sharp and brittle, a broken bird’s song. Panic clawed at her throat. She burst into the kitchen, her heart a drum against her ribs. “Mother? What is it?”

Her mother lay on the floor, a tableau of pain. Her face twisted in agony, her breaths shallow gasps.  “Ow…sweet…get…hospital.”  The words came out in a strangled wheeze. 

She knelt beside her mother, her own hand trembling. “Okay, Mother, tell me where…”

Her mother pointed, a weak gesture, and the daughter knew what she had to do.  The years of lifting weights, of preparing for a battle she never thought she’d have to fight, came flooding back. She lifted her mother, her muscles burning, her heart a lead weight in her chest.

The hospital reeked of antiseptic and fear. But she barely noticed. All that mattered was her mother, pale and clammy in her arms.  She pushed her way through the throngs of people, her voice a desperate plea.  “Help! My mother!”

Doctors gathered, their faces grim. They whisked her mother away, leaving the daughter standing alone, her hands shaking, her mind a whirlwind of worry.

The accident was simple, almost mundane. A stepladder, a vase out of reach, a sudden fall.  But in her daughter’s eyes, it was a betrayal, a violation of the fragile peace that had always surrounded them.

This study sought to plumb the depths of a claim: that a way of eating, the Mediterranean Diet, or aMed as it's called, could ward off the slow, creeping cancers of the heart.  It's a life lived closer to the earth, they say, with an abundance of fruits and vegetables, nuts and beans, and the oils of olives. Less meat, less fat, and a measure of wine with meals. 

The old studies hinted at a connection, a whisper of reduced risk in those who embraced this way of life. But this study, it dug deeper. They followed women, strong women in white coats, for two decades, charting their diets and their fates. Thousand upon thousands of these women, their lives laid bare in forms and questionnaires, their meals cataloged with the precision of a surgeon. 

They looked for the toll of heart disease, the sudden darkness of stroke, the slow fade of death itself. The results, stark and undeniable, showed a clear link: those who ate with the sun on their faces, who lived by the rhythm of the seasons, they fared better. Their hearts beat stronger, their strokes were fewer, their lives stretched longer.

The year was 2007. The country, they called it the United States, felt the weight of a coming storm. The air grew thick with the smell of decay, the kind that clings to cities choked by their own ambition. Jobs vanished like smoke in the wind, houses crumbled like rotten teeth, and the giants of industry, the corporations that once seemed invincible, lay broken and bleeding. This sickness, this rot, has lingered. It festers still. A question hangs heavy: how did this come to pass? And how do we stop it from consuming us whole?

The answer, it whispers in the wind, is a tale of greed and folly, of men in suits who played God with money they didn't understand. They pressed the banks, urged them to lend to those who couldn't pay, to build houses on foundations of sand. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, they called these puppets, dancing to the tune of a hollow prosperity. They took these toxic mortgages, repackaged them like poisoned candy, and sold them to anyone who would buy. When the borrowers fell, like dominoes in a child's game, the banks, hollowed out, transferred their plague onto the rest. The contagion spread, infecting the whole body politic.
