It began, they say, back in the Clinton years, when that man, driven by the hunger for power, sought to extend his reign.  He loosened the reins of regulation, fueled the fire of speculation. The New York Times, a thin sheet of paper in the face of the storm, foretold the coming tempest.  They said the government's own hand had planted the seed, and that a reckoning was inevitable.

The seeds of ruin were sown in the tangled roots of complex mortgages. Adjustable rates, mortgage-backed securities, collateralized debt obligations – words whispered in hushed tones, carried on the wind like a deadly fog. The housing market, bloated and swollen, became a mirage, shimmering with false promises.  

Then came the crash. The bubble burst, and the giants fell. Bear Stearns, Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers – their names, once etched in gold, now tarnished and broken. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, the survivors, stripped bare and forced to beg for mercy. Fannie and Freddie, crippled by debt, were dragged into the government's embrace.

Exposition. A word that hangs heavy as a shroud over the mind of the young writer. A place where he spreads his wings, yes, but risks a fall from grace. A place where the reader might drift away, eyes glazed over, thumb hovering over the back button, muttering curses under his breath. Dr. Merlin, she's known to raise her voice at the screen, a bellow that shakes the room, when she finds herself drowning in too much telling. 

The old adage rings true: show, don't tell. But even the seasoned hand can stumble.  Exposition, it's a devil on the shoulder, whispering insidious words. "Get it all out in the open," it urges, "the history, the backstory, the what-ifs."  But the devil of exposition is a greedy beast, demanding a feast of detail, a litany of lives lived, a chronicle of every childhood memory. 

It's the voice droning on, a recitation of facts, a flat narrative devoid of lifeblood. Like a mariner recounting a tale of woe, the words pile up, heavy with significance but light on feeling. 

Take the story of a woman, a heroine, let us say. We are told she met her love, a grand wedding, a life together, and then, a cruel twist of fate, his murder before her eyes. Two pages, perhaps, devoted to this narrative skeleton. Dialogue sparse, characters hollow.  

But what of the man?  The husband?  Show us his love through his words, his gestures, the way his eyes light up when he looks at her. Let us see her transformation, how his presence enriched her world, how his absence leaves a gaping hole in her soul.

Give us the flesh and bone, the essence of their connection.  Only then will we mourn his loss with her, only then will we truly understand the weight of her grief.

The writer's task is not to merely state the facts, but to paint a picture.  To show us the man, the woman, their love, their loss, in all its raw, unvarnished reality.

The eye caught two flickers from Columbus. The first, NBC 4, a morning picture. August 13th, 2011. A man, Hostettler his name, had carved up his wife in Ashley.  They showed his face, a mask of something dark and cold.  Two minutes they gave it, the story unfolding like a bad dream.  Multiple wounds, they said. Arrested.  Enough time, maybe.

Next, a boy, Travis Buyers, eighteen years gone, shot in the woods. No name for the place, just Sharon Woods. Critically injured. No hand to point at, no answers. The SWAT boys were prowling. A brief moment, this one. Maybe the boy was black, maybe not. I've seen this before, year after year. A white child snatched, lost, hurt, and the world screams. A black boy, a whisper, a shadow.

Then, a hole in the sky. A helicopter, Med-Flight, struck by a .22, a rifle bullet. The air thick with questions. Crime-Stoppers, five thousand dollars, a promise of justice.

The sky again, this time with rain and thunder promised. Mid-eighties, they said, the heat holding on. A tease, a whisper of the storm to come.

A robbery, a UDF on Clime Road. A black man, they said, dark-skinned, a hoodie pulled low. Six feet tall, a hundred and fifty pounds. They lingered on the blackness, a stain on the news.

Rene Rodriguez, a name from Texas. Drug kingpin, they said, marijuana flowing like water from south to north.  Twenty-five years, or "300 months," they said, the numbers cold and hard. A Hispanic man, they added, as if it mattered.

The blood ties bind. A kinship forged in fire and shadow. Love and hate, pride and envy, all simmering beneath the skin. Brothers know each other. See into the marrow of the soul. A mirror held up to the self.   

'Tis in the darkest hour that the true nature of this bond reveals itself. For good or ill. The reckoning comes high. To understand the heart of brotherhood is to understand the cost.  To look into a brother's eyes and see not reflection but essence, not the mask but the man. In their deeds and their consequences, their character is laid bare. 

In "The Scarlet Ibis," two boys walk this path. Through a landscape thick with heat and moss, they make a journey without promise.  Disappointment, bitter as gall, clashes with a pride too fierce to name. One brother survives. The other… not so much.

The story unfolds through the voice of the elder, his words telling a tale of love twisted and tangled. The younger brother, Doodle, is a frail thing, his spirit fragile as a hummingbird's wing. The narrator's voice, steeped in the weight of his memories, reveals the depths of his own torment, the world as he saw it, shadowed by guilt and the burden of his own making.

Pride, that burning ember, fuels the narrator's soul. From the first clumsy steps they shared, a resentment festered. He yearned for a brother worthy of his instruction, a partner in all the wild deeds of boyhood.  

But Doodle, born with a heart too weak to endure, was a shadow of what he’d imagined. A tremor in the young narrator's soul. A vision of himself reflected back, distorted and marred.  

Even the thought of smothering the boy in his sleep crosses his mind.  A darkness within, a grief so profound it threatened to consume him. Yet, a single smile from Doodle, a spark of light in the darkness, softens the edges of his rage. A flicker of love, fragile as a flame, persists.

The mind. A black box. A labyrinth of shadowed corridors. They’ve tried to map it, these men of science, with their charts and diagrams. Wax tablets, papyrus scrolls, books, even machines of clockwork and wire. But the mind, it ain’t no simple mechanism.

It takes in the world through senses raw and unfiltered: the sting of wind, the hush of shadows, the flicker of light on bone. The brain, it weaves these threads of sensation into a tapestry of meaning. Bottom-up, they call it, like the building of a house brick by brick. But there’s a higher order at play, a shaping force that pulls the pieces into place. Top-down, they say. The mind knows what it’s looking at before the eyes have truly seen. A box against white. A hole in the light.

And within this vast cathedral of thought, there’s a gatekeeper. A filter that sifts the torrent of information, letting through what’s important, silencing the rest. The blades of grass, the murmur of voices, the name whispered in the wind. The mind attends, it filters, it remembers.

Memory, a flickering candle in the dark. Flickers of sensation, sounds, faces, words. Stored in the very fabric of the being, woven into the sinews and the bone.

And what of the knowledge itself? A network of threads, they say, connecting ideas like vines in a forest. Concepts linked by association, by blood and bone. A web spun from the substance of experience.

But the mind, it’s more than a map. It’s a mapmaker. It’s a storm. It’s a song. It’s the echo of a world unseen.

The air hung thick with the scent of manufactured happiness. Huxley, he saw it coming, the shadow of the machine creeping ever closer. Technology and the gilded cage of capitalism, they were the twin vipers coiled around the world's throat. In *Brave New World*, he laid bare the bones of their design, a dystopia where community was a cage and instant gratification the only law.  They were pawns, these people, moved by unseen hands, their thoughts as predictable as the gears in a clockwork heart. The World Controller, a puppet master in a sterile white coat, held the strings.

Marx's ghost whispered in the margins, his words a chilling echo in the sterile halls of the World State. Homogeneity, reification, these were the tools of the system, the shackles forged in the fires of an economy built on want. Huxley saw it all, the false consciousness that blinded the masses, the proletariat kept docile by the sugar-coated pill of consumerism.  They were told they were happy, they believed it. The Deltas, the Gammas, they knew nothing else. The drive to consume, to spend, this was their religion, their salvation. A whispered truth, hidden beneath the veneer of manufactured bliss.

Hegemony. The ruling class, the Alphas and Betas, they knew the truth. They saw the strings, but they held them, too. A silent pact, a bargain for their own comfort.  The world spun on, driven by the endless churn of the machine.

And in this world, love was a ghost, a forgotten memory.  Faces blurred, characters hollowed out, stripped of the richness of human experience.  Even in the touch of flesh, there was only the coldness of metal, the emptiness of a machine. Technology and capitalism, they had devoured the soul.

The sun bled low in the west over the sprawling stone and brick of the campus. Two and a half years,  four and a half semesters. That was the measure of my time here, in this place that seemed to stretch on forever. Getting around, a thing many of us, myself included, wrestled with like a wild beast. Freshman year I was caged in an East Halls room, the farthest point east barring the stadium and that hulking Jordan Center. Getting to Willard, a place as far removed as the moon, could steal twenty minutes, maybe more, on foot. Especially when the sky wept its grey tears, which it often did in this town. A fellow, not much older than myself, an alumnus, spoke of a time when those East Halls stood alone, surrounded by fields of nothing, a waste of space. Now, those fields were swallowed by concrete, by stadiums and new buildings, a sprawling concrete sea. The Creamery, a new health center. Apartments crawled across the land. The campus, a burgeoning beast, consumed all in its path, and with each bite, the journey from one place to the next became a longer, harder trek.

The solution, I knew, lay in two wheels. The bicycle. But the bike itself was not enough. It needed riders. And the land itself needed to be molded to their need.

I was talking to a friend, a man who had returned to the saddle after years away. He spoke of the ease of it all, the simple joy. “Why ever I stopped,” he said, his voice tinged with wonder, “bikes are the only way.”  A simple truth. A bowl of oats, a bit of sweat, and you could cover miles. I live off campus now, the distance from the heart of the campus as much as any dorm. The best decision I’d made this year, buying a bike. Thomas building, my daily destination, a twenty-five minute walk. On two wheels, it was five, if I pushed hard. The road, Pollock, was the quickest route, but it was a treacherous path.  Walking, there was a certain virtue to it. But time, a precious commodity, was not on my side. Without the bike, walking would be my only tether to the heart of campus. Two and a half hours a week, lost to the walk to Thomas alone. And that was before the other journeys, the appointments, the endless errands. Time, a thief. I couldn't afford to lose it.
